There were two waves of colonisation. Commercial Revolution Era sparked by access to spice and silk of the east powered by gold and silverIndustrial Revolution sparked by access to larger markets and source of raw materials powered by currenciesThe United States of America was acquired during the commercial revolution. In 1776, the Americans declared independence. King George was afraid that losing the colonies would weaken the empire. But instead, the US-British trade relations flourished even further and the empire became more powerful with an independent USA. After all, they could continue access to American markets and raw materials without costing the British a standing army in North America. By the 1900s, the empire had given complete autonomy to Canada and Australia under the queen but only as symbol of state. By the end of World War II, England realised it was cheaper to let the colonies (now loyal subjects of the crown) govern and defend themselves and let the United States do all the policing of the world. The British realised tjey did not need to directly administer the colonies which cost money. All they needed was a symbol of state to lead them to the “correct” way, that is creating their own policies that serves both the interest of their home countries AND THE CROWN. Brexit was possible because the British kept its empire now known as the Commonwealth of Nations. They will continue to have access to Australian produce, Canadian soldiers, Singaporean and Malaysian ports, Indian spices, a multinational manpower and US soldiers. They can’t dictate these former slaves of course but the queen can easily rally them to her cause. England and Japan are the only monarchies in the world that can never be threatened by republicanism. Their relinquish of absolute monarchy to constitutional monarchy saved them.
